awd_titl_txt: Scientific and Ethical Implications of the Emerging Data Sciences for the Interpretive Social Sciences: An Interdisciplinary Workshop: Arlington, VA - Fall 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop explores the scientific and ethical implications of open science initiatives and calls for research transparency for understandings of "data" in qualitative social science research. Building on prior NSF-funded projects, participants will consider evolving and competing meanings of data given recent developments in data management, including examinations of data collection, sharing, and analysis. This will be accomplished by drawing together proponents of open science and scholars with diverse perspectives about possible and appropriate management of qualitative data, including ethicists, social scientists, representatives from federal and private funding agencies, and public policy scholars. Participants will explore the ways emerging data sciences, broadly conceived, are driving priorities for the interpretive social sciences and reshaping our understanding of them. It will also identify key challenges to better representing the methodological pluralism of the social sciences, including competing accounts of "data" and associated implications for managing qualitative research results. Workshop outcomes will inform decision-making in the science policy and funding communities regarding science and data management in the ethnographic/humanistic social sciences. 

This workshop considers consequences of widespread, often technologically-enabled approaches to data management and the rising influence of data-reliant industries for qualitative social science research.  A primary workshop goal is to systematically articulate where and how the push towards open science and data management is compatible with qualitative social science research and where it might not be.  In so doing, the workshop will examine the implications of different conceptualizations of "data" across the social sciences, and invite discussion of how these often unacknowledged and underplayed differences figure in competing processes of sense-making, including how data are collected, classified, interpreted, and archived, and the concomitant ethical implications of each of these processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Building directly on a series of prior NSF-funded workshops, this workshop sought to explore the implications of recent open science initiatives and calls for greater research transparency for our understandings of "data". In this workshop, we considered both evolving and competing meanings of data, in light of recent developments in data management, to include collection, sharing and analysis, as these impact and influence science policy, funding, and -- directly or indirectly -- expectations for the humanistic, qualitative or interpretive social sciences. 

We convened open science proponents from STEM and social scientific backgrounds, science ethics professionals, sociologists and anthropologists from both the academy and industry, representatives from federal and private funding agencies, and scholars in the public policy realm, all of whom brought diverse perspectives about possible and appropriate management of qualitative data. The focus of the workshop was twofold: attention to the ways emerging data sciences, broadly conceived, are driving priorities for, and perhaps also reshaping our understanding of, the interpretive social sciences; and a focus on identifying key challenges to better represent and incorporate the epistemological pluralism of the social sciences, including competing accounts of "data" and associated implications for the management of ethnographic or qualitative research results.

This workshop considered the consequences of what are now widespread and often technologically-enabled approaches to the management of data, and the rising influence of data-reliant industries.  An important workshop goal was to articulate, for the social sciences, where these projects are compatible and where they might not be. In so doing, the workshop addressed implications of epistemological differences across the social sciences, and invited discussion of how these differences, often underplayed, figure in competing processes of sense-making, including how data are collected, classified, interpreted, archived, and made available to others, as well as examining the concomitant ethical implications of each of these processes. 

The workshop discsussions have been collected as a series of manuscripts to be published in the Spring of 2024 as a special issue of the journal Science, Technology, and Society. We have also begun a Community of Practice, hosted by the Online Ethics Center, to continue these discussions with scholars/practitioners beyond the workshop participants. 

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2024
Modified by: Dena K Plemmons
